title: Winters' Formula for Metabolic Acidosis Compensation
description: Calculates the expected arterial pCO₂ compensation in pure metabolic acidosis to assess the adequacy of respiratory compensation. This formula helps clinicians determine if respiratory compensation is appropriate, insufficient, or excessive in patients with metabolic acidosis.

parameters.name: measured_pco2
parameters.description: Measured arterial pCO₂ (optional, for comparison with expected value)

result.name: expected_pco2
result.description: Expected arterial pCO₂ for metabolic acidosis compensation

ranges.interpretation: The measured pCO₂ is significantly lower than expected, suggesting respiratory overcompensation or a concurrent primary respiratory alkalosis. Consider mixed acid-base disorder.
The measured pCO₂ is within the expected range for metabolic acidosis, indicating appropriate respiratory compensation. Focus on treating the underlying cause of metabolic acidosis.
The measured pCO₂ is higher than expected, suggesting inadequate respiratory compensation or a concurrent primary respiratory acidosis. Consider respiratory impairment or mixed acid-base disorder.

references: Winters RW, Engel K, Dell RB. Acid-base physiology in medicine. A self-instruction program. London, UK: The London Company; 1967.
Adrogué HJ, Madias NE. Secondary responses to altered acid-base status: the rules of engagement. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2010;21(6):920-923. doi: 10.1681/ASN.2009121211
Berend K, de Vries AP, Gans RO. Physiological approach to assessment of acid-base disturbances. N Engl J Med. 2014;371(15):1434-1445. doi: 10.1056/NEJMra1003327
Kraut JA, Madias NE. Serum anion gap: its uses and limitations in clinical medicine. Clin J Am Soc Nephrol. 2007;2(1):162-174. doi: 10.2215/CJN.03020906
formula: Expected pCO₂ = 1.5 × [HCO₃⁻] + 8 (± 2 mmHg). The measured pCO₂ should fall within ± 2 mmHg of the calculated expected value for appropriate respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis.
notes: Applies only to pure metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
Normal range for serum bicarbonate: 22-28 mEq/L
Normal range for arterial pCO₂: 35-45 mmHg
Formula assumes steady-state conditions (6-24 hours after onset)
Does not apply to mixed acid-base disorders
Measured pCO₂ within ±2 mmHg of expected indicates appropriate compensation
Deviation >2 mmHg suggests concurrent respiratory disorder
Should be used in conjunction with clinical assessment and other laboratory values
pH should be <7.35 to confirm metabolic acidosis
Calculate anion gap to determine if acidosis is high or normal anion gap
Formula may be less accurate in severe acidosis (bicarbonate <10 mEq/L)
Consider arterial blood gas analysis for accurate pCO₂ measurement
Venous bicarbonate may be used as approximation but arterial preferred for pCO₂
